bestBHT.bht: Timothy, our brother and fellow-worker with God in the Gospel of Christ, was sent to confirm and exhort the Thessalonians in their faith. Gospel ministers serve as instruments of God, establishing His work. Timothy, a faithful minister and laborer, provided comfort and exhortation to the Thessalonians in their trials, reminding them that their faith was not in vain. Through his example, the Thessalonians received reassurance of their faith and found solace in knowing that Paul, their beloved apostle, persevered through challenges with unwavering faith.

Henry Alford: Timothy, our brother and fellow-worker with God in the Gospel of Christ.
There does not appear to be any special reason for this honorable mention of Timothy, further than the disposition to speak thus highly of him on the part of the Apostle.
In order to confirm you, and exhort you on behalf of your faith.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Gospel ministers do the work of God with Him, for Him, and under Him.
He is the true establisher: ministers are His 'instruments.'
The Thessalonians in their trials needed both comfort and exhortation.
Albert Barnes: One of the richest tokens of affection which can be shown to any people, is to send to them a faithful minister of God.
In parting with him, therefore, for your welfare I showed a strong attachment for you. I was willing to endure personal inconvenience, and additional toil, in order to promote your welfare.

The object of sending Timothy was to suggest such topics of consolation as would sustain them in their trials - that is, that he was the Son of God; that the people of God had been persecuted in all ages; that God was able to support them, etc.
Marvin Vincent: Diakonov minister and diakonia ministry or service are common expressions of service to Christ or to men. Paul habitually uses them in this way."
Diakonoi is used of ministers of Satan, 2 Corinthians 11:15, and diakonov of the civil magistrate, Romans 13:4.
To establish [στηριξαι] . See on Luke 22:32; Introd. to Catholic Epistles, Vol. 1, p. 625; 1 Peter 5:10; 2 Peter 1:12.
John Calvin: It is, on the other hand, a great thing that he deprives himself of a brother and fellow-laborer, and one to whom, as he declares in Philippians 2:20, he found no equal, inasmuch as all aimed at the promotion of their own interests.
It is with good reason that he says that he had sent Timothy with this view — that they might receive a confirmation of their faith from his example.

Thus, when the Thessalonians heard that Paul was going on with indefatigable zeal, and was by strength of faith surmounting all dangers and all difficulties, and that his faith continued everywhere victorious against Satan and the world, this brought them no small consolation.
Philip Schaff: Our brother and fellow-labourer with God."
Paul bestows these commendatory titles on Timothy partly from his affection for his young assistant, partly to illustrate still further his love for the Thessalonians.
Timothy was sent in the interest of their faith, to explain to them that the troubles in which they were involved were no proof that their faith was foolish, and to encourage them to maintain it.
John Gill: He was a minister of the things of God, of the mysteries of God, of the truths of his Gospel; and who ministered according to the ability God gave him, and was faithful to him.

He was a labourer, and not a loiterer in the Lord's vineyard; one that laboured in the word and doctrine, that studied to show himself a workman, that gave himself wholly to meditation, reading, exhortation, and doctrine.

These characters are given of Timothy, partly to show what honour was done the Thessalonians, in sending such a messenger to them; and partly that they might receive him with the greater respect, and treat him according to his character, office, and dignity.

bhtAttempts.bht: Timothy, our brother and fellow-worker with God in the Gospel of Christ, was sent to the Thessalonians to confirm and exhort them on behalf of their faith. Gospel ministers, like Timothy, are instruments of God, the true establisher, who serve Him in His work. In their trials, the Thessalonians needed comfort and exhortation, which Timothy provided through his ministry. As a minister, Timothy faithfully served and labored for God, explaining to the Thessalonians that their trials did not discredit their faith and encouraging them to hold on to it. Through Timothy's example, the Thessalonians received confirmation of their faith and found consolation in knowing that Paul, their beloved apostle, continued to overcome hardships and obstacles through his unwavering faith in Christ.

Timothy, our brother and fellow-worker, was sent to confirm and exhort the Thessalonians in their faith. Gospel ministers serve God as His instruments and establish His work. They provide comfort and exhortation to those facing trials. Timothy, a faithful minister and laborer, explained to the Thessalonians that their trials didn't discredit their faith, encouraging them to persevere. Through his example, the Thessalonians received confirmation of their faith and found consolation in knowing that Paul, their beloved apostle, overcame hardships through his unwavering faith.

Timothy, our brother and fellow-worker with God in the Gospel of Christ, was sent to confirm and exhort the Thessalonians in their faith. Gospel ministers serve as instruments of God, establishing His work. In their trials, the Thessalonians needed both comfort and exhortation. Timothy, a faithful minister and laborer, explained to them that their trials did not discredit their faith and encouraged them to maintain it. Through his example, the Thessalonians received confirmation of their faith and found consolation in knowing that Paul, their beloved apostle, continued to overcome hardships through his unwavering faith.

Timothy, a faithful minister and laborer, provided comfort and exhortation to the Thessalonians in their trials, reminding them that their faith was not in vain. Through his example, the Thessalonians received reassurance of their faith and found solace in knowing that Paul, their beloved apostle, persevered through challenges with unwavering faith.

Timothy, our fellow-worker with God in the Gospel of Christ, was sent to confirm and exhort the Thessalonians in their faith. Gospel ministers, serving as instruments of God, establish His work. In their trials, the Thessalonians needed both comfort and exhortation. Timothy, a faithful minister, explained that their trials did not discredit their faith, urging them to persevere. Through Timothy's example, the Thessalonians received confirmation of their faith and found consolation in knowing that Paul, their apostle, overcame hardships through unwavering faith.
